#â€‹719 â€” January 17, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Learn Yjs and Building Realtime Collaborative Apps in JavaScript â€” Yjs is a CRDT (Conflict-free replicated data type) library for building collaborative and local-first apps. CDRTs are powerful but can be tricky to â€˜getâ€™ which is why this new interactive Yjs tutorial is so valuable. A great way to learn about building collaborative, syncing webapps from the groundÂ up.

Jamsocket

Bun v1.1.44: The Fast JS Runtime Adds On-Demand Frontend Bundling â€” The popular, high-performance alternative JavaScript runtime has extended its Bun.serve() HTTP handler with support for bundling frontend apps on demand using HTMLÂ imports.

Ben Grant

Protect Against Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in RealÂ Time â€” With WorkOS Radar you can detect, verify and block harmful behaviour, protecting your app with advanced device fingerprinting. Stop fake signups, stop free tier abuse, and stop bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

WorkOS sponsor

A Checklist for Your tsconfig.json â€” What I love about Dr. Axel is when heâ€™s done the hard work of figuring something out for himself, he writes it down. So it goes here, with his journey to set up a good tsconfig.json for hisÂ projects.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

IN BRIEF:

  • The Angular team shares a brief update on how they're working on Angular's strategy forÂ 2025.

  • ğŸ‘½ Alien Signals are coming to Vue 3.6... (it's basically a really fast way to handleÂ signals.)

  • Tired of seeing this everywhere in your code? Dave Rupert has a fun way to turn it into a single glyph in VS Code.

RELEASES:

  • Electron 34 â€“ The JS, HTML and CSS desktop app framework updates to Chromium 132, Node 20.18.1, and adds a way to access the JavaScript call stack of unresponsiveÂ renderers.

  • Puppeteer 24 â€“ Popular high-level API to control Chrome or Firefox.

  • Cypress 14 â€“ Easy testing for anything that runs in a browser. Now supporting the latest versions of React, Angular, Svelte & Vite for component testing.

  • Storybook 8.5, ESLint 9.18.0, ESLint Config Inspector 1.0, AngularFire 19.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

A Look at Regular Expression Pattern Modifiers â€” You may be familiar with using flags to change the behavior of regexes, but Dr. Axel looks at a proposal bringing a way to change regex flags within subexpressions (e.g. /^[a-z](?-i:[a-z])$/i;). Itâ€™s at stage 4 and should land in ECMAScriptÂ 2025.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

Accessibility Essentials Every React JS Developer Should Know â€” If youâ€™re an experienced frontend developer, these might be second nature to you by now, but this is a good roundup of the entry level â€˜table stakesâ€™ for frontend accessibility, whether using React orÂ not.

Martijn Hols

Write More Maintainable JavaScript with AI Code Reviews â€” CodeRabbit is your AI-powered code review companion that deeply understands the JavaScript codebase. Free for openÂ source.

CodeRabbit sponsor

Five Years of React Native at Shopify â€” Five years ago, Shopify said React Native was the future for mobile development at their company and they meant it, with every mobile app moving to RN over time. Hereâ€™s what they learnt along the way and why theyâ€™re sticking withÂ it.

Mustafa Ali (Shopify)

Revealed: React's Experimental Animations API â€” <ViewTransitionÂ /> is based on the browser's View Transition API. Itâ€™s only in pre-release versions of React, but Matt is armed with examples for you to get a feel for theÂ potential.

Matt Perry (Motion)

ğŸ“„ All JavaScript Keyboard Shortcut Libraries are Broken â€“ Reflections on long standing complexities with the myriad ways of detectingÂ keypresses. Jack Duvall

ğŸ“„ JavaScript Hashing Speed Comparison: MD5 vs. SHA-256 â€“ You shouldnâ€™t be using MD5 anyway, but you especially shouldnâ€™t be using it with the misconception that itâ€™sÂ faster. Daniel Lemire

ğŸ“„ 5 Technical JavaScript Trends You Need To Know About in 2025 Alexander T. Williams

ğŸ“„ Creating a Generative Artwork with Three.js Eduard Fossas

ğŸ“„ JavaScriptâ€™s Promise.race and Promise.all Are Not â€œFairâ€ Chris Krycho

ğŸ“„ Node.js's Type Stripping Explained Marco Ippolito

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

â™Ÿï¸Â Chess.js: A Library to Manage a Chess Game â€” Provides move generation, validation, piece placement, check/checkmate/stalemate detection â€“ "everything but the AI!" v1.0 offers a rewrite to TypeScript and a variety ofÂ enhancements.

Jeff Hlywa

ğŸ’¡ Chess Engines: A Zero to One is a neat article digging into the technicalities of implementing a chessÂ engine.

react-nil 2.0: A React 'Null Renderer' â€” An interesting experiment to use React in situations where you donâ€™t need it to render anything, but you want to use hooks, suspense, context, and other bits of the React lifecycle. Like in, say, a Node app. Maybe this CodeSandbox example will provoke someÂ ideas.

Poimandres

ğŸ”Â file-type 20.0: Detect the File Type of a File, Stream or Data â€” For example, give it the raw data from a PNG file, and itâ€™ll tell you itâ€™s a PNG. Uses a â€˜magic numberâ€™ approach so is targeted at non text-based formats. v20 adds support for yet more formats, including JARs, Word/Excel templates, and now supports ZIPÂ decompression.

Sindre Sorhus

Node Web Audio API 1.0: A Web Audio API Implementation for Node â€” More accurately, itâ€™s a set of Node bindings for a Rust-powered non-browser implementation of the Web AudioÂ API.

IRCAM â€“ Centre Pompidou

âš™ï¸ Vue Spring Bottom Sheet â€“ A lightweight, flexible solution for bottom sheets in VueÂ apps. megaarmos

âš™ï¸ Act â€“ A Go-powered tool that looks at your repo's GitHub Actions, uses Docker to grab the necessary images, and runs the tasksÂ locally. Nektos

âš™ï¸ Svar â€“ A new suite of open source UI components for Svelte, React, and Vue. XB Software

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Optimize Your Next.js App's Metadata - Discover practical ways to boost your site's SEO and visibility by customizing metadata inÂ Next.js.

ğŸ¹ STRICH: Add blazing fast and reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning to your web apps. Free demo app and 30-day trialÂ available.

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

  • Perspective 3.3 â€“ Streaming data viz and analytics component. The core is written in C++ and compiled to WebAssembly. The homepage shows it offÂ well.

  • eslint-plugin-functional 8.0 â€“ ESLint rules to disable mutation and promote functionalÂ approaches.

  • React Testing Library 16.2 â€“ DOM testing utils that encourage goodÂ practices.

  • Happy DOM 16.6 â€“ Cross-runtime JS implementation of a web browser sansÂ UI.

  • PowerGlitch 2.4 â€“ Tiny library to add a 'glitch' effect to images on theÂ Web.

  • ğŸ¤– node-llama-cpp 3.4 â€“ Run LLMs locally with bindings toÂ llama.cpp.

  • Faker 9.4 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • Gridstack.js 11.3 â€“ Build responsive interactive dashboardsÂ quickly.

  • Mineflayer 4.25 â€“ Create Minecraft bots inÂ JavaScript.

item.title: ã€Bun's on a roll with v1.2ã€‘bunä¸v1.2
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹720 â€” January 24, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Bun 1.2: A Big Step Forward for the Fast JS/TS Runtime â€” The JavaScriptCore-based Bun continues to up its server-side runtime game with strides forward in Node.js compatibility, performance boosts, and new APIs for interacting with S3 and S3-like object stores as well as Postgres. If youâ€™d prefer to be â–¶ï¸ introduced to Bun 1.2 with a keynote-style video, it's a goodÂ watch.

Ashcon Partovi and the Bun Team

ğŸ¦– ..and by no means should we forget Deno whose team have published a roundup of all of Deno's progress in the pastÂ year.

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript Datagrid â€” A fast and flexible DataGrid for building modern web apps. Key features and virtualized rendering are included in the core grid module. Pick & choose special features to keep your app small. Built for JavaScript, extended to Angular, React, andÂ Vue.

Wijmo From MESCIUS inc. sponsor

ğŸ¤–Â Transformers.js v3.3: Machine Learning and AI for the Web â€” This is a dry release announcement but I wanted to highlight the rapid pace that this exciting library is making for browser-based NLP, speech recognition, vision, and now text-to-speech use cases (live TTS demo here - it takes a while to load though). Itâ€™s also being used in Firefox for various enhancements (seeÂ below).

Hugging Face

IN BRIEF:

  • The creator of SolidJS says that Angular and Vue are the frameworks to watch in 2025, while reflecting on JS framework progressÂ generally.

  • A year ago, Kelly Sutton wrote about his company's move away from React but how did it pan out? In Moving On from React, a Year Later he explains how things have goneÂ since.

  • JSON Query is a neat, flexible JSON querying language. The demos really sell itÂ IMHO.

  • The ESLint project takes a look back at ESLint's 2024 year in review.

  • GitHub has unveiled sub-issues, issue types, and advanced search for issues.

RELEASES:

  • Rspack v1.2 â€“ Fast Rust-based Web bundler adds a peristent cache feature that improves hot start performance by up toÂ 250%.

  • Node v23.6.1 (Current), v22.13.1 (LTS), v20.18.2 (LTS), v18.20.6 (LTS) to resolve some security vulnerabilities.

  • Capacitor 7.0 â€“ Build cross-platform native apps/PWAs with web technologies.

  • React Native 0.77 â€“ Now with enhanced styling capabilities.

  • Vitest 3.0 â€“ The fast Vite-native testing framework.

  • NestJS 11, Storybook 8.5, Unpic 1.0, Inferno 9.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

ğŸ•’Â JavaScript Temporal is Coming (For Real!) â€” We first mentioned the Temporal API proposal providing a better way to handle dates and times in JavaScript almost five years ago (in issue 496!) but now it really is almost here. Brian explains its basic concepts and where initial support is starting toÂ appear.

Brian Smith

Avoiding anys with Linting and TypeScript â€” any is TypeScriptâ€™s famous type fallback/safety hatch but if you can avoid it, you can benefit more from TypeScriptâ€™s type-checking features. Josh shares some tips to do justÂ that.

Josh Goldberg

[Workshop] How to Build Testing Culture on Your Team â€” Join our live session to learn strategies for gaining buy-in, balancing testing, and integrating it into dailyÂ workflows.

Sentry sponsor

ğŸ¤–Â Running Inference in Web Extensions â€” Firefox Nightly is shipping with a new API that can let you use their AI runtime for offline machine learning tasks in Web extensions you create. It uses the previously mentioned Transformers.js and is already used in Firefox 133 to provide alt text for images inÂ PDFs.

Tarek ZiadÃ© (Mozilla)

ğŸ“„ Generating Test Values using JavaScript Generators Peter Leonov

ğŸ“„ TypeScript Enums: Use Cases and Alternatives Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ“„ Fetch and HTTP/2 Support in Node, Bun and Deno Georges Haidar

ğŸ“Š A Deep Dive into Initial Load Performance Nadia Makarevich

ğŸ“„ Improving UI Performance by Optimizing Our Debouncer Atul Jalan (Compose)

ğŸ“„ Angular Clean Coding Fundamentals Jonathan Gamble

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

deck.gl 9.1: GPU-Powered Large Scale Data Visualization â€” deck.gl provides a way to create complex yet high performance data visualizations composed of multiple layers (examples). It can be used in a vanilla JS way or through React components and itâ€™s ready forÂ WebGPU.

OpenJS Foundation

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” Next-level testing in any editor, 15x faster with Interactive Time Travel Debugger, real-time insights & advanced coverage in a newÂ UI.

Wallaby Team sponsor

ArkType 2.0: Runtime Validation Library â€” An easy-to-deploy solution for schema validation that can infer TypeScript definitions 1:1 and use them as optimized validators for your data, both at runtime and for immediate type-level feedback in yourÂ editor.

ArkType

NodeBB v4.0.0 Released: Node.js Powered Forums â€” Offers a classic forum experience in a modern Node.js-shaped guise. v4 adds support for federation between instances and the widerÂ 'fediverse.'

NodeBB, Inc.

SRCL: Build React Apps with 'Terminal Aesthetics' â€” The homepage is a live demonstration of what SRCL has to offer. Itâ€™s a suite of React components and styling to recreate a monospaced, terminal-likeÂ atmosphere

Internet Development Studio Company

ğŸ¶Â Chiptune.js: Module / Tracker File Player â€” A library for playing â€˜moduleâ€™ music files like MOD, XM and S3M. (Demo.)

Chiptune Contributors

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

â˜€ï¸ The main JS conference returns to a unique venue! Enjoy 50+ talks & workshops, a food truck festival, networking with 1.5K devs, & 10% off with codeÂ JSWEEKLY!

  • GoReleaser v2.6 â€“ A popular 'release engineering' tool in the Go world has just added support for Bun andÂ Deno.

  • React Admin 5.5 â€“ Framework for building B2B frontendÂ interfaces. Now with React 19 and React Router 7Â support.

  • React Scan 0.1 â€“ Automatically scan for performance issues and eliminate slow renders in yourÂ app.

  • ğŸµ ChordSheetJS 12.0 â€“ Library for parsing and formatting chords and chord sheets. (Demo.)

  • Fortune Sheet 1.0 â€“ Drop-in Excel-like spreadsheetÂ control.

  • ApexCharts 4.4 â€“ Popular JS charting library.Â (Demos.)

  • YouTube.js 13.0 â€“ JS client for YouTube's privateÂ API.

  • BlockNote 0.23 â€“ 'Notion-style' block-basedÂ editor.

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹721 â€” January 31, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Things People Get Wrong About Electron â€” A long-time maintainer of the wildly successful Electron cross-platform app framework stands by the technical choices Electron has made over the years and defends it against some of the more common criticismsÂ here.

Felix Rieseberg

Standard Schema: A Common Interface to Schema / ValidationÂ Libraries â€” From the creators of Zod, Valibot and ArkType comes a fantastic bit of collaboration to define a common interface to use JavaScript and TypeScript schemaÂ libraries.

McDonnell, Hiller, and Blass

JavaScript: The Hard Parts â€” Take your knowledge to the next level with the most loved JavaScript course in the industry. Deepen your understanding of the most important aspects of JavaScript. This highly rated video course goes under the hood, looking at callbacks, higher-order functions, object-oriented JS, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

A WebAssembly Compiler That Fits in a Tweet â€” Or 192 bytes, if you prefer. This is a look into a fantastic little bit of JavaScript hacking that can compile arithmetic expressions into WebAssembly you can run very easily. You can learn a lot in so little timeÂ here.

Mariano Guerra and Patrick Dubroy

Announcing TypeScript 5.8 Beta â€” Itâ€™s that time again. Whatâ€™s new? Support for using require() for ES modules in Node 22+, checked returns for conditional and indexed access types, startup and building optimizations & more. While not a huge release overall, it's particularly good for Node devs.

Daniel Rosenwasser

ğŸ’¡ One neat 5.8 feature is --erasableSyntaxOnly, a way to ensure that 'type stripping' techniques still result in runnable code by disallowing TypeScript-exclusive features likeÂ enums.

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¬ Remember Honeypot's well-received Node.js documentary? (If not, watch it!) Now there's a trailer for an Angular documentary dueÂ soon.

  • There's been a lot of chatter about Create React App being effectively 'deprecated' due to a lack of updates from Meta. Turns out, it is deprecated, but the process is now being managed gracefully and some basic React 19 support will be mergedÂ in.

  • A developer came up with an approach to making npm packages 5% smaller using Zopfli compression and asked the npm team to consider it. Ultimately the decision was no for a variety of reasons.

  • â­ The Syntax YouTube channel presents â–¶ï¸ a fun countdown of the top 15 most starred JavaScript projects on GitHub. This is so well putÂ together.

RELEASES:

  • Astro 5.2 â€“ The popular framework adds Tailwind CSS 4 support and moreÂ niceties.

  • pnpm 10.1 â€“ The alternative, efficient packageÂ manager.

  • Prisma 6.3 â€“ Popular ORM for Node.js andÂ TypeScript.

  • â­ Phaser v4 Beta 5, Node.js 23.7, npm 11.1, Neutralinojs 5.6

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

The Modern Way to Write JavaScript Servers â€” The irony is that while Node popularized JavaScript on the server (though Netscape was doing it in the 90s) this modern, standardized cross-runtime approach doesnâ€™t work on Node ...yet ;-)

Marvin Hagemeister

Introducing Mentoss: The fetch Mocker â€” A new approach to mocking global fetch() calls (in both browsers and server-side runtimes) inspired by previous attempts like Nock andÂ MSW.

Nicholas C. Zakas

Wish Your AI Co-Pilot Actually Knew Your Codebase? â€” Try the most context-aware Developer AI. Augment deeply understands your codebase, documentation, andÂ dependencies.

Augment Code sponsor

Lessons from Scaling WebSockets for a JavaScript App â€” Scaling WebSockets for real-time apps presents hidden complexities. Compose shares some lessons learnt the hardÂ way.

Atul Jalan

ğŸ“„ Computing with Tuples in TypeScript â€“ A way to bring objects of different types together but in a lighter way than keyedÂ objects. Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ“„ How Long is a Second in JavaScript? â€“ What may seem like a straightforward query is actually one of surprisingÂ complexity. Iago Lastra

ğŸ“„ Adding Maps to Your Pages with Leaflet.js â€“ Quick, easy, and open source toÂ boot. Raymond Camden

ğŸ“„ How to Use Node's fs in the Browser for Custom Playgrounds Ivan Chebykin

ğŸ“„ Building a QR Code HTML Web Component Scott Jehl

ğŸ“„ How to Build a CMS with React Admin Thibault Barrat

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

docxtemplater: Generate docx and pptx Documents from Templates â€” Generate Word and PowerPoint files dynamically by merging against templates (ideal for invoices, contracts, certificates, etc.) Itâ€™s open source (MIT or GPLv3), but the creator has a commercial version with more extensions (e.g. to work with Excel). GitHub repo and featureÂ demos.

Edgar Hipp

ğŸ“ŠÂ Plotly 3.0: A JavaScript Graphing Library â€” A high-level, declarative charting library, built on top of D3 and stack.gl, with over 40 chart types, including 3D charts, statistical graphs, and SVG maps. v3 is largely to remove deprecations, fix bugs, and a switch to esbuild.

Plotly, Inc.

Using Clerk SSO to Access Google Calendar and Other ServiceÂ Data â€” Leverage Clerkâ€™s social sign in providers to easily access service data on behalf of yourÂ users.

Clerk sponsor

Emittery 1.1: A Simple, Modern Async Event Emitter â€” A small, async event emitter for Node and the browser, and now with support for AbortController.

Sindre Sorhus

jsontr.ee: Visualize JSON Structures as Dynamic SVGÂ Diagrams â€” You can try it out on this playground, which provides the option to download the diagram as PNG, or use it in an app with customizableÂ styles.

Lou AlcalÃ¡

DBOS Transact v2: Lightweight Durable Execution in TypeScript â€” Durable execution means persisting the execution state of your program while it runs, so if itâ€™s interrupted or crashes, it resumes from where it left off â€“ ideal for long-running or business-critical workflows. Docs.

DBOS, Inc.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

Protect your SaaS app with advanced device fingerprinting from WorkOS Radar. Stop fake signups, free tier abuse, bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

jscanify 1.3: JavaScript Document Scanning Library â€” Given raw photos of documents, this can do paper detection (along with glare suppression), distortion correction, highlighting and extracting. See some visual examples or try it outÂ here.

ColonelParrot

Ruck 9.0: A React Webapp Framework for Deno â€” A lean React-based way to build modern React apps with Deno using features like ESM, dynamic imports, HTTP imports, and import maps with no transpilation orÂ bundling.

Jayden Seric

  • OpenPGP.js 6.1 â€“ OpenPGP implementation forÂ JavaScript.

  • wavesurfer.js 7.9 â€“ Waveform rendering andÂ playback.

  • Poku 3.0 â€“ Cross-platform JavaScript testÂ runner.

item.title: ã€The projects that shaped JavaScript in 2024ã€‘åœ¨2024å¹´å¡‘é€ JavaScriptçš„é¡¹ç›®
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹718 â€” January 10, 2025

Read on the Web

ğŸ—“ï¸ Friday is the new Thursday! If you were a JavaScript Weekly reader several years ago, you might remember it always landed on Fridays and after getting caught out by a variety of big news items landing on Thursdays in recent years, we're backÂ ;-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

â­Â 2024's JavaScript Rising Stars â€” Itâ€™s time to fully wave goodbye to 2024, but not before Michael Rambeauâ€™s annual analysis of which JavaScript projects fared best on GitHub over the past year. Even if you dislike GitHub stars as a metric for anything, this remains a great way to get a feel for the JavaScript ecosystem and see what libraries and tools have mindshare in a variety of niches. A fantastic roundup asÂ always.

Michael Rambeau

A Look at Import Attributes â€” Itâ€™s always a pleasure to see Dr. Axel blogging about JavaScript again, and heâ€™s back with one of his typical deep dives into a newer ECMAScript feature: import attributes. This feature provides an inline syntax for attaching metadata to module imports such as for importing non-JavaScript modules (e.g. JSON, WASM orÂ CSS).

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

How to Enable End-to-End Testing with Synthetic Monitoring â€” Synthetic Monitoring helps you launch new features with confidence and speed. Learn how you can create robust end-to-end test suites, spend less time on false positives, and proactively catch errors before they get toÂ production.

Datadog sponsor

Nodeâ€™s New Built-in Support for TypeScript â€” Node.js v23.6.0 (Current) has just been released and makes Nodeâ€™s new type-stripping features work by default, so you can just run node file.ts and it Should Just Workâ„¢. Dr. Axel explains how it works and what the limitationsÂ are.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¥Š The Deno vs Oracle fight over the JavaScriptâ„¢ trademark continues as Oracle has informed Deno they're not going to voluntarily relinquish the mark. Deno's job now is to show how JavaScript has long been used as a generic term and hasn't been controlled by Oracle.

  • The Express.js team has posted about the project's recent revival and its plans to push Express.js forward inÂ 2025.

  • â„ï¸ The 'WinterCG' Web Interoperable Runtimes Community Group, an effort to promote standards around runtime interoperability of JavaScript runtimes, has moved to Ecma International and is now known as WinterTC (TC55).

  • ğŸ“º Node.js creator Ryan Dahl gave a talk at GOTO Chicago 2024 about Deno 2, covering Deno's differences to Node and what Deno 2.0 (and JSR) has to offer JavaScript developers, complete with liveÂ demos.

RELEASES:

  • pnpm 10 â€“ The efficient npm alternative no longer runs lifecycle scripts of dependencies for security reasons, hashing algorithms have been upgraded to SHA256, and lots of minorÂ tweaks.

  • Bun v1.1.43 â€“ The high-performance runtime gets first class S3 support, an HTML bundler, and can output V8 heap snapshots (which is quite something as Bun uses JavaScriptCore, notÂ V8).

  • ğŸ”  Tesseract.js 6.0 â€“ The popular pure JS multilingual OCR library has resolved a variety of memory leakÂ issues.

  • Docusaurus 3.7 â€“ The popular docs-oriented site generator goes full React 19.

  • Node.js v22.13.0 (LTS) â€“ The permission model system is nowÂ stable.

  • Puppeteer 24.0, RxDB 16.0, Ember 6.1, QuickJS 0.8

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

The Future of htmx â€” htmx is an increasingly popular way to enhance HTML and actually write less JavaScript on the frontend. This post reflects on how htmx would like to be â€˜the new jQueryâ€™, not least in the sense that one of the projectâ€™s goals is to push the ideas of htmx into the HTML standard itself, as in this set ofÂ proposals.

Gross and Petros

You Don't Need Next.js â€” As much as Next.js is considered the React meta-framework of choice, if your requirements are modest, simply going with plain React offers numerous benefits in terms of simplicity and speed, as seenÂ here.

Benny Kok

Introducing Clerk SDKs for Vue and Nuxt â€” Official @clerk/vue & @clerk/nuxt SDKs for authentication integration with pre-built UI components in Vue/Nuxt apps.

Clerk sponsor

Using TypeScript Without Build Tools â€” Chris Coyier enjoys the benefits of TypeScript while developing, but actually compiling it to JavaScript in various scenarios is less endearing. Weâ€™ve learnt (above) that Node can now run .ts files directly, but what other projects support the use of TypeScript without buildÂ tools?

Chris Coyier

ğŸ“„ Using a JavaScript Component Inside a Haskell App â€“ Did you know Haskellâ€™s main compiler supports integrating withÂ JavaScript? Mateusz GoÅ›linowski

ğŸ“„ Crafting a Dreamy Particle Effect with Three.js and GPGPU Dominik Fojcik

ğŸ“„ Build Your Own Site Speed Testing Tool with Puppeteer Henry Price

ğŸ“„ Sharing a Variable Across HTML, CSS, and JavaScript Chris Coyier

ğŸ“„ Benchmarking GraphQL Solutions in the JS/TS Landscape Tomasz NieÅ¼urawski

ğŸ“„ Shallow Clones vs Structured Clones Phil Nash

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

PostalMime: A Universal Email Parsing Library â€” An email parsing library happy in most JS runtimes. Takes the raw source of emails and parses them into their constituentÂ parts.

I'll let you decide if this one is fun or frightening! Whether or not this will work depends on your PDF reader or browser support, but it works with Chrome and Firefox, atÂ least.
